column4: everytime I want to run the debugger (gdb) through eclipse or code blocks the whole graphical system hangs, I can still move the mouse, but the X server doesn't even respond to ctrl+alt+backspace and I can only access the computer via ssh... what could cause this?
what are you running gdb on?
what do you mean? I'm running it on ubuntu 8.04 inside either eclipse IDE or code::blocks
attaching gdb halts the process you attach to (until you hit "continue" in the debugger). This makes gdb-ing processes like Xorg or your compositing manager tricky.
I am trying to debug a self written application, I never meant to debug the X server
then I don't understand what's going on here, unless you're breaking into your application while it has the server grabbed or something.
are you debugging a commandline or X app?

I've compiled it and am trying to run it with the debugger, but only one second after I hit the "debug" button in toolbar of either code::blocks or eclipse the graphical system hangs, as described above
there's no problem running it with gdb from the command line
I don't know what those buttons do (I don't use either ide). Does just attaching gdb to a process from the commandline fail the same way? If not, any idea what's different there?
if you can ssh in you can maybe get the /proc/$(pidof gdb)/cmdline out
I'm not familar with this, what's the purpose of getting it's command line?

well, if gdb works ok when invoked from a terminal window then presumably the ide is either invoking gdb differently or telling it to do something else differently. If it's invoking it differently /proc/$(pidof gdb)/cmdline would tell.
I've gotten the cmd line from 'ps aux | grep gdb', it states 'gdb -nx -fullname -quiet -args <filename>' but when running it this way from the command line it works as well
ugh. It must be sending something to gdb that makes it do something stupid, but I can't think of a convenient way to think of what. If you kill gdb through ssh does the system recover?
does your ide log what it sent and received from gdb anywhere?
I don't think so, if it does, than it's well hidden
